questions.question: Question 1: Leukocyte-adhesion deficiency type 2 is due to the absence of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Leukocyte-adhesion deficiency (LAD) type 2 is due to the absence of Sialyl-Lewis X. Physiologically Sialyl-Lewis X has the necessary ligand for the selectins which bind to leukocytes. Inherited defects in leukocyte adhesion: • Type 1 - defect in the biosynthesis of the  2 chain shared by the LFA-1 and Mac-1 integrins • Type 2 - absence of sialyl-Lewis X, the fucose containing ligand for E- and P-selectins. It is due to 
a defect in the fucosyltransferase, the enzyme that attaches fucose moieties to protein backbones. The major clinical problem in both conditions is recurrent bacterial infections due to inadequate 
granulocyte function.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements is false about Chédiak-Higashi syndrome?

options.b: It has an autosomal recessive inheritance
options.d: Granules are absent in white blood cells

questions.explanation:
297 
Sold by @itachibot Leukocytes contain giant granules in Chédiak–Higashi syndrome as seen in peripheral blood 
smears. They are due to aberrant phagolysosome fusion. The image shows giant granules in a neutrophil in Chédiak–Higashi syndrome. Chédiak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition. The defective fusion of 
phagosomes and lysosomes results in defective phagocytes function and susceptibility to 
infections. The abnormalities are neutropenia, defective degranulation, and delayed microbial killing, 
causing: • Albinism - melanocytes • Nerve defects - nervous system cells • Bleeding disorders - platelets 298 
Sold by @itachibot The gene associated with this disorder encodes a large cytosolic protein called LYST, which is 
believed to regulate lysosomal trafficking.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 2-month-old baby was brought with complaints of fever and fast breathing for 5 days, and 
was diagnosed with pneumonia. Further history revealed baby had recurrent infections. 
Blood culture revealed infection from Nocardia spp. Nitroblue tetrazolium test turned out to 
be negative. Which of the following statement is false regarding this condition?

options.b: It is due to oxidase deficiency

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario suggests chronic granulomatous disease. It is due to a macrophage-rich 
chronic inflammatory reaction, not lymphocytic. Chronic granulomatous disease is a defect in bacterial killing and renders patients susceptible to 
recurrent bacterial infections. The name of this disease comes from the macrophage-rich chronic 
inflammatory reaction that tries to control the infection when the initial neutrophil defense is 
inadequate. This often leads to collections of activated macrophages that wall off the microbes, 
forming granulomas.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient presents with recurrent swelling of the face and lips as shown with vomiting and 
diarrhea when emotionally stressed. What is the most likely deficiency?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hereditary angioneurotic edema. It is due to 
the deficiency of C1 inhibitors. Hereditary angioneurotic edema is an autosomal dominant disorder, which is more common than 
complement deficiency states. Targets of C1 inhibitors are proteases, specifically C1r and C1s of the complement cascade, factor 
XII of the coagulation pathway, and the kallikrein system. Deficiency of C1 inhibitor leads to 
unregulated activation of kallikrein. This increases the production of vasoactive peptides such as 
bradykinin. It causes episodes of edema affecting the skin and mucosal surfaces such as the larynx and the 
gastrointestinal tract. This may result in life-threatening asphyxia or nausea, vomiting, and 
diarrhea after minor trauma or emotional stress.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 4-month-old baby was brought with severe diaper rash. The parents gave a history of 
recurrent infections in the past 4 months which required frequent hospitalization. On 
examination white patches were present in oral mucosa which could be scraped easily. The 
biopsy of the thymus showed remnants of Hassall's corpuscles. Which of the following 
statements is false about this condition?

options.c: It is due to defect only in cell mediated immune response
options.d: B cell count can be normal

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). The biopsy 
of the thymus showing remnants of Hassall's corpuscles indicates it is due to adenosine 
deaminase (ADA) deficiency. SCID is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune 
responses. Usually the defect lies in the T-cell compartment with secondary impairment in 
humoral immunity. Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and 
failure to thrive. Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T 
cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease 
(GVHD). Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of 
pathogens, including: • Candida albicans • Pneumocystis jiroveci • Pseudomonas • Cytomegalovirus • Varicella There are 2 types of SCID based on inheritance: 1. X-linked SCID is the most common form and hence it is more common in boys than in girls. 
The genetic defect is the mutation in the common -chain (c) subunit of cytokine receptors. T-cell 
numbers are greatly reduced, and although B cells may be normal in number, antibody synthesis 
is impaired because of the lack of T-cell help. The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated 
epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus. 300 
Sold by @itachibot 2. Autosomal recessive is most commonly caused due to deficiency of the enzyme adenosine 
deaminase (ADA). The deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its 
derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP). They are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially 
those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T 
lymphocytes. In the two most common forms (c mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid 
of lymphoid cells. In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be 
found. Note: X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

questions.question: Question 7: Which gene is not involved in SCID?
questions.explanation:
BTK mutation causes X-linked agammaglobulinemia and not SCID (severe combined 
immunodeficiency). Severe combined immunodeficiency is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune 
responses. In this condition, the following genes are involved: • JAK3 • RAG1 • IL-7R Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of 
pathogens, including: • Candida albicans • Pneumocystis jiroveci • Pseudomonas • Cytomegalovirus • Varicella

questions.question:
Question 8: A 9-month-old baby was brought with a cough and difficulty in breathing. The baby was 
admitted with similar complaints in the past. On auscultation, coarse crepitations were heard. 
Quantitative serum immunoglobulin analysis was done and serum IgG, IgA, and IgM levels 
were low. His cellular immunity was found to be normal. Which of the following is false about 
his condition?

options.b: Germinal centres of lymph nodes are underdeveloped
options.c: Manifestation is seen usually after 6 months of age

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bruton agammaglobulinemia/ X-linked 
agammaglobulinemia (XLA). Even though it is an immunodeficiency disease, it is 
paradoxically associated with autoimmune diseases such as arthritis and dermatomyositis in 35% 
of individuals. The classic form of this disease has the following characteristics: • B cells are absent or markedly decreased and the serum levels of all classes of immunoglobulins 
are decreased • T-cell mediated reactions are normal • Germinal centers of lymph nodes, Peyer’s patches, the appendix, and tonsils are underdeveloped 301 
Sold by @itachibot • Plasma cells are absent throughout the body XLA is characterized by the failure of B-cell precursors (pro-B cells and pre-B cells) to develop into 
mature B cells. It is associated with mutations in a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase called Bruton 
tyrosine kinase (Btk). The related gene is located on the long arm of the X chromosome. This X-linked disease is seen 
almost entirely in males. The disease usually does not become apparent until about 6 months of 
age, when maternal immunoglobulins are depleted. Affected individuals are susceptible to infections with: • Bacteria that are normally opsonized by antibodies and cleared by phagocytosis • Haemophilus influenzae • Streptococcus pneumonia • Staphylococcus aureus • Giardia lamblia - intestinal protozoan that is normally resisted by secreted IgA, causes persistent 
infections • Enteroviruses • Echovirus • Poliovirus • Coxsackievirus

questions.question:
Question 9: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with delayed development. On examination, he had 
the following appearance. Further workup revealed hypocalcemia and an atrial septal defect. 
Chromosomal studies showed deletion of 22q11. All are true about this syndrome except: 290 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: It is associated with T cell deficiency
options.b: Thymic aplasia is a prominent feature
options.d: Failure of development of 3rd and 4th pharyngeal arches

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario with the image suggests DiGeorge syndrome. It results from the failure 
of the development of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. They give rise to the thymus, the 
parathyroids, some of the C cells of the thyroid, and the ultimobranchial body. The absence of cell-mediated immunity causes poor defense against certain fungal and viral 
infections. The T-cell zones of lymphoid organs, i.e. paracortical areas of the lymph nodes and the 
periarteriolar sheaths of the spleen, are depleted. Ig levels may be normal or reduced, depending 
on the severity of the T-cell deficiency.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is least likely to be a feature in a patient with Hyper-IgM syndrome?

options.a: It has X-linked mode of inheritance
options.b: They have normal serum IgG levels
options.c: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia can be seen
options.d: They have normal B-cell and T-cell numbers

questions.explanation:
The serum of patients with Hyper-IgM syndrome contains extremely low levels of IgG. In Hyper-IgM syndrome production of IgM antibodies is normal but the ability to produce IgG, 
IgA, and IgE antibodies is deficient. There are normal or elevated levels of IgM, no IgA or IgE, 
and extremely low levels of IgG. It affects the ability of helper T cells to deliver activating signals 
to B cells and macrophages. However, B cells and T cells counts are normal. It is mostly an X-linked disease, that has mutations in the gene encoding CD40L located on Xq26. 
If the disease is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, then there are loss-of-function 302 
Sold by @itachibot mutations involving either CD40 or the enzyme called activation-induced cytidine deaminase 
(AID). Those with CD40L mutations are also susceptible to pneumonia caused by the intracellular 
organism Pneumocystis jiroveci. This is due to CD40L-mediated macrophage activation, a key 
reaction of cell-mediated immunity being defective. Recurrent pyogenic infection occurs because 
the level of opsonizing IgG antibodies is low. Occasionally, the IgM antibodies react with blood cells, giving rise to autoimmune hemolytic 
anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. In older patients, the proliferation of IgM-producing 
plasma cells that infiltrate the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract is seen.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 3-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and Pneumocystis jiroveci 
pneumonia. The flow cytometry analysis of the boy (Boxes 3& 4) is shown below (Boxes 1 
& 2 are normal). What is the most likely diagnosis? 291

The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the 
production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens, is unaffected, accounting for the 
presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome. The given clinical scenario and the flow cytometry is suggestive of Hyper IgM syndrome. The flow

quadrant 4, which means that there is CD 40 deficiency. The deficiency of the CD40 and its absence in B cells interferes with class switching and the 
production of memory cells. The B-cell response to antigens is unaffected, accounting for the 
presence of increased IgM antibodies. Hence, the condition is known as Hyper IgM syndrome. Given below is the explanation of how to interpret flow cytometry results: 303

questions.question:
Question 12: Patients with isolated Ig A deficiency would have associated deficiency of which of the 
following IgG subtypes?
questions.explanation:
Isolated IgA deficiency is associated with deficiency of IgG subtypes IgG2 and IgG4. IgA deficiency-affected individuals have extremely low levels of both serum and secretory IgA. It 
may be familial or acquired in association with toxoplasmosis, measles, or some other viral 
infection. Because IgA is the major antibody in external secretions, mucosal defenses are weakened, and 
infections occur in the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urogenital tracts. Symptomatic patients 
commonly have recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea. IgA-deficient patients have a high frequency of respiratory tract allergy and a variety of 
autoimmune diseases, particularly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following are mutated in X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome is due to mutations in the gene encoding an adaptor 
molecule called SLAM-associated protein (SAP). It is characterized by an inability to eliminate Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), eventually leading to 
fulminant infectious mononucleosis and the development of B-cell tumors. 304 
Sold by @itachibot In about 80% of cases, the disease is due to mutations in the gene encoding the adaptor molecule 
SAP. Defects in SAP contribute to attenuated NK cell and T-cell activation, resulting in increased 
susceptibility to viral infections. Option B: LYST gene is associated with Chediak-Higashi syndrome. Option C: BTK gene is associated with Isolated growth hormone deficiency type III. Option D: TBX1 gene is associated with 22q11.2 deletion syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following lymphoid tissue findings is seen most commonly in patients with 
common variable hypogammaglobulinemia?
questions.explanation:
Normal B-cell count is most commonly seen in lymphoid tissues of individuals with the common 
variable hypogammaglobulinemia. It is a heterogeneous group of disorders in which the common feature is 
hypogammaglobulinemia, generally affecting all the antibody classes, but sometimes only IgG. In contrast to X-linked agammaglobulinemia, most individuals with common variable 
immunodeficiency have normal or near-normal numbers of B-cells in the blood and lymphoid 
tissues. These B cells, however, are not able to differentiate into plasma cells. FDA approved XEMBIFY in 2019, 20% immunoglobulin solution for subcutaneous injection. It is 
indicated for the use of primary humoral immunodeficiency disorders in patients 2years of age 
and older.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 3-year-old boy is brought with complaints of red rashes over his skin. His mother says that 
the child will be constantly scratching the rashes. On asking any previous history she says the 
child keeps getting recurrent infections which mostly require hospitalization. Blood 
investigations showed a low platelet count. Which of the following is false regarding this 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The given history with eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia points towards Wiskott–
Aldrich syndrome. In this condition, IgM levels in the serum are low. Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome is caused by mutations in the gene encoding the Wiskott–Aldrich 
syndrome protein (WASP), which is located on Xp11.23. The X-linked disease is characterized by 
thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, resulting in early 
death. Platelets are small in size. The thymus is morphologically normal, at least early in the course of 
the disease, but there is the progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and in the 
T-cell zones (paracortical areas) of the lymph nodes, with variable defects in cellular immunity. Patients do not make antibodies to polysaccharide antigens, and the response to protein antigens 
is poor. IgM levels are low, IgG is usually normal, while the levels of IgA and IgE are often 
elevated. Patients are prone to developing B-cell lymphomas.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 5-year-old girl was brought to the OPD with complaints of repeated falls while walking for 
the past 1 year. She had difficulty in eating, gripping, or holding things. On examination, 
hand mouth incoordination and slurring of speech were noted. On ocular examination, the 
following finding was seen. All are true about this condition except: 293 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: There is defective production of IgA and IgG2
options.b: Affected gene is located on chromosome 11
options.d: There is increased risk of malignancy

questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario and image showing telangiectasia are diagnostic of 
ataxia-telangiectasia. It is an autosomal-recessive disorder, not autosomal dominant. 305 
Sold by @itachibot The most prominent humoral immune abnormalities are defective production of IgA and IgG2. 
The gene responsible for this disorder is located on chromosome 11 and encodes a protein called 
ATM. The ATM protein is a sensor of DNA damage (double-strand breaks), and it activates p53 by 
phosphorylation. Ataxia-telangiectasia is characterized by abnormal gait (ataxia), vascular malformations 
(telangiectases), neurologic deficits, increased incidence of tumors, and immunodeficiency. It may 
affect both B and T cells. There is a high incidence of lymphomas and leukemias.

questions.question: Question 17: Human immunodeficiency virus affects CD4 cells due to their interaction with which protein?
questions.explanation:
The CD4 cells are affected by HIV due to their interaction with gp120. HIV-1 virion is spherical and contains an electron-dense, cone-shaped core surrounded by a lipid 
envelope derived from the host cell membrane. Target cells of HIV include CD4+ helper T cells 
(worst affected), monocyte-macrophages, and dendritic cells. The virus core contains: • Major capsid protein p24 • Nucleocapsid protein p7/p9 • Two copies of viral genomic RNA • The three viral enzymes (protease, reverse transcriptase, and integrase) The viral core is surrounded by a matrix protein called p17, which lies underneath the virion 
envelope. The viral envelope is studded by two viral glycoproteins, gp120 and gp41, which are 
critical for HIV infection of cells. Viral glycoprotein gp120 binds to CD4+ cells in the host. CXCR4 and CCR5 function as 
coreceptors for HIV-1 entry into CD4+ cells. This binding leads to a conformational change in 
gp41 causing exposure of a hydrophobic region called the fusion peptide at the tip of gp41. This 
peptide inserts into the cell membrane of the target cells (e.g., T cells or macrophages), leading to 
the fusion of the virus with the host cell. The image below shows the pathogenesis of HIV infection. 306 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: Which of the following cell types is not a target for the initiation and maintenance of HIV 
infection?
questions.explanation:
The neutrophil is not a target for the initiation and maintenance of human immunodeficiency 
virus (HIV) infection. HIV enters the body and affects T cells, dendritic cells, and macrophages. Particularly, memory 
and activated T cells are infected, but it is inefficient at productively infecting naive (unactivated) 
T cells. Completion of the viral life cycle in latently infected cells occurs only after cell activation, and in 
the case of most CD4+ T cells, virus activation results in cell lysis. The image below shows the pathogenesis of HIV infection. 307 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: Which is the most common CNS neoplasm in HIV patients?
questions.explanation:
The most common central nervous system (CNS) neoplasm in patients with HIV infection is 
primary CNS lymphoma. Lymphomas are the most common CNS neoplasm in immunosuppressed individuals, including 
those with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) and immunosuppression after 
transplantation. They are associated with latent infection with Epstein–Barr virus (EBV). The vast 
majority of primary brain lymphomas are of B-cell origin. At least two mechanisms appear to underlie the increased risk of B-cell tumors in HIV-infected 
individuals. They are: • The unchecked proliferation of B cells infected with oncogenic herpes viruses in the setting of 
profound T-cell depletion (AIDS). • Germinal center B-cell hyperplasia in the setting of early HIV infection. The most common site for lymphoma in patients with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome 
(AIDS) is the central nervous system (CNS).

questions.question:
Question 20: A 25-year-old man, who is HIV-positive, presents with generalized lymphadenopathy. Which 
of the histopathological features is least likely to be seen on lymph node biopsy?

options.d: Collection of monocytoid B Cells in sinuses

questions.explanation:
Hematoxylin bodies are seen in lymph nodes in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Features of AIDS-related lymphadenopathy: Early stages of HIV infection: • Florid hyperplasia of B cell follicles • Follicle lysis • Monocytoid B cells in sinuses • Neutrophils and dermatopathic lymphadenopathy • The interfollicular zone shows vascular proliferation, which may progress to Kaposi sarcoma Late stages of HIV infection: • Severe lymphoid involution • Possible hyalinization of the germinal centers • Burnt-out lymph nodes, which become atrophic and may harbor numerous opportunistic 
pathogens, often within macrophages

questions.question:
Question 21: A 50-year-old HIV-seropositive man presents with raised violaceous plaques over the legs. 
Microscopy shows a lesion in the dermis with dilated, jagged vascular channels lined and 
surrounded by plump spindle cells. It contains red cells with marked hemorrhage, 
hemosiderin pigment, and mononuclear inflammation. Mitotic figures are also seen. Which 
organism is associated with this tumor?
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is Kaposi sarcoma, caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8). Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular neoplasm, that is highly associated with acquired immunodeficiency 
syndrome (AIDS). It is the most common cancer seen in patients having AIDS. Though the 308 
Sold by @itachibot incidence of Kaposi carcinoma reduced, it still occurs in 2-3% of HIV-infected individuals. The pathogenesis of Kaposi sarcoma that is caused by HHV8 includes: • A virally encoded G protein that induces VEGF production, stimulating endothelial growth • The lytic infection caused by HHV8 increases the pro-inflammatory cytokines • HHV8 encoded proteins inhibit the p53 induced apoptosis The given images show coalescent red-purple macules and plaques of the skin and the histologic 
appearance of Kaposi sarcoma, demonstrating sheets of proliferating spindle cells:

questions.question:
Question 22: A 45 -year-old HIV-positive patient has patchy pneumonia. Smears of induced sputum and 
sedimented cells from lavage fluid stained with methenamine silver are as seen below. Which 
is the most likely organism implicated? 295 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The smears stained with methenamine silver show black-colored stained cysts resembling 
the crushed ping pong balls of Pneumocystis jirovecii. 309 
Sold by @itachibot Approximately 15% to 30% of untreated HIV-infected people develop pneumonia during the 
course of the disease. It is mainly caused by the fungus P. jirovecii (reactivation of prior latent 
infection). 310 
Sold by @itachibot Amyloidosis and Graft Rejection
